I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Strengthening Public Resource Management Program. The 
report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) to support implementation of program 
reforms, and if the Board approves the program, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by 
the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
2.  The program aims to strengthen public resource management in Tajikistan through 
improved tax policy and administration, more effective and efficient social safety net programs, 
and improved public financial management.1 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Tajikistan recovered from the economic impacts of the global financial crisis, supported 
by (i) the Government of Tajikistan’s anti-crisis program;2 (ii) a rebound in remittances (18% 
year-on-year in 2010) resulting principally from the economic upturn in the Russian Federation; 
and (iii) higher global prices for aluminum and cotton, which represented 83% of total exports in 
2010. However, while the real gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate for 2010 was 6.5%—
an increase from 3.4% in 2009—it is still below the 7.4% average growth experienced in 2005–
2008 (Table 1). Recovery continues to be affected by tighter credit to the private sector due to 
growing stress in the banking system,3 and the recent hike in imported food prices. These 
factors are likely to continue restraining real GDP growth in 2011 (forecast at 5.5%) and 2012 
(forecast at 6.0%). Recovery also remains dependent on sustained economic recovery in the 
Russian Federation, based on Tajikistan’s reliance on trade and remittance inflows. (See the 
economic and financial analysis and country economic indicators).4 
 
4.  Increases in salaries and pensions and higher international commodity prices are expected 
to  keep  inflation  levels  high  (10.0%  estimated  for  2011,  close  to  the  9.8%  figure  of  2010).5 
Unemployment also remains high (11.5% in 2009), and close to 1 million Tajiks, or about 40% of the 
workforce, work abroad.6 Remittances from migrant workers are the main source of income of many 
families, averaging 41.1% of GDP in 2005–2009. Tajikistan remains the poorest country in the 
Commonwealth of Independent States, with the lowest per capita GDP ($1,900 in 2009) and the 
lowest per capita social expenditures. The weak social protection system offers limited social 
assistance benefits with little impact on poverty. Fiscal spending on social assistance (0.5% of 
GDP) is the lowest in Central Asia.7 Although declining steadily since 1999, poverty remains high,

5.  Increasing tax revenue during 2005–2008 enabled the government to increase social 
expenditures. However, the global financial crisis resulted in a stall in GDP growth and a 
decrease in tax revenues. To help maintain critical social expenditures, ADB provided a $40 
million grant to Tajikistan in 2009,9 and other development partners provided grants for the 
same purpose in 2009 and 2010.

spending and to finance much-needed public investment. This translates into significant state

8.  The  overall  fiscal  balance  in  2009,  excluding  the  public  investment  program,  was 
maintained at a close to expected deficit of 0.6% of GDP, despite lower than expected growth. 
For 2010, the government estimates a 1.0% deficit, due to less than expected revenues, which 
required additional cuts in nonessential expenditures until the end of the year. In 2011, the 
government is planning a deficit not higher than 1.0% of GDP (Table 2). Public debt (including 
public guaranteed debt) remains high at 36.4%. Net international reserves are estimated at 
$447.0 million, providing import cover for only about 1.6 months. 12 The current account deficit in 
2010 is estimated at 3.5% of GDP, a decrease from 4.9% in 2009, but it is expected to increase 
to 4.5% of GDP in 2011 and 5.5% of GDP in 2012. 
 
9.  For many years, the government has not fully prioritized the sectors being covered by 
the program, but is now strongly committed to making improvements in these areas. The 
support and inducement of a program grant will support the government in implementing long-
needed reforms and will provide resources needed to ensure that critical social expenditures are 
included in the 2011 and 2012 budgets (Table 2).

10.   The program is consistent with Tajikistan’s national development strategy for 2006–
2015,13 which has the improvement of public administration as one of its three main goals. It is 
also consistent with Tajikistan’s  poverty reduction strategy for 2010–2012,14 which aims to 
broaden  access  to  basic  social  services.  Governance  and  gender,  two  themes  under  the 
program, are two of the thematic areas of the Tajikistan’s country partnership strategy 2010–
2014  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).15 The  program  contains  features—e.g., 
operationalizing internal audit audits and reviews of pilot social service delivery projects—that 
will improve governance by strengthening accountability. The program also includes gender 
mainstreaming features, including an analysis of the gender impact of the pilot programs to

B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The  program’s  expected  impact  is  increased public  funding for  social  policies.  The 
expected outcome is strengthened public resource management in Tajikistan. See the design 
and monitoring framework (Appendix 1) and the sector assessment summary (footnote 10). 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
12.  The program has three outputs: (i) selected aspects of tax policy and administration will be 
improved; (ii) the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection will design, implement, and evaluate 
social safety net pilots; and (iii) selected aspects of public financial management will be improved. 
 
1.  Output 1: Selected Aspects of Tax Policy and Administration Improved 
 
13.  The government is committed to modernizing tax policy and administration. The program 
supports  implementation  of  the  Tax  Administration  Development  Program  for  2011–2015, 
approved by the government in 2010. The Tax Administration Development Program sets out 
objectives, targets, and indicative costs of reforms for (i) functional reorganization of the Tax 
Committee  and  its  offices,  (ii)  introducing  performance  management,  (iii)  building  human 
resources capacity, and (iv) introducing information and communication technology in the tax 
system. Under the first tranche, the government has carried out Tax Code amendments which 
(i) eliminate selected value-added tax exemptions (including on medical services provided by 
the private sector, sales of handicrafts, and air navigation services) and profit tax exemptions on 
the dividends payable to local enterprises from other local enterprises, (ii) rationalize the rates of 
property tax by removing a broad range of rates and establishing single rates for various 
categories of property (commercial, residential, and others), (iii) authorize the Tax Committee to 
develop procedures for electronic submission of tax returns to facilitate taxpayer compliance 
with filing requirements and move to a risk-based audit system, and (iv) permit installment 
payments by taxpayers with arrears based on credible financing plans agreed upon between the 
Tax  Committee  and  such  taxpayers.  The  Tax  Committee  has  increased  the  number  of 
taxpayers to be handled by the Large Taxpayers Inspectorate (LTI) by 20% from the baseline of 
December 2010 (from 202 taxpayers to 245), with another increase of 20% planned for 2012 as 
part of the agreed reforms under the second tranche.  
 
14.  By August 2012, normative acts will be issued by (i) the Tax Committee to implement the 
Tax Code amendments; and (ii) the local governments of at least Dushanbe, Isfara, Khudjand, 
Kulyab and Kurgantyube (the five largest cities by population) to implement amendments to the 
Tax Code related to property tax. The Tax Committee will set up a technical working group to 
provide  operational  advice  on  tax  reforms.  The  program  includes  TA  to  support  the  Tax 
Committee in implementing agreed reform actions for the second tranche, including  
(i)  modernizing the LTI by developing an information technology strategic plan with 
detailed costing, developing detailed procedures and software, and initiating a 
pilot for electronic submission of tax returns by large taxpayers;

(iii)  increasing efficiency by adopting clear written internal business processes and

(vii)  approving improved forms for various categories of taxes to improve databases 
and fight tax fraud and corruption; and  
(viii)  improving the tax audit system by developing risk indicators and launching work 
on creating a risk-based planning system for tax audits.  
 
15.  The program will assist the government to transform the LTI into a model organization 
that can efficiently handle an increasing number of large taxpayers and collect a much larger 
share  of  taxes  in  Tajikistan.  Consultative  processes  with  key  stakeholders,  including 
professional women and representatives of the business community, will be established to 
develop and fine tune tax system simplification and reform proposals.18 
 
2.  Output 2: Social Safety Net Pilots Designed, Implemented, and Evaluated 
by the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection  
 
16.  The program will support reforms aimed at improving the effectiveness, efficiency, and 
accountability of public expenditures in social protection, in particular two new pilot programs that 
the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection (MOLSP) has designed and started implementing. The 
phased implementation of the pilot for noncash-based transactions for pension payments through 
individual bank accounts has been started in four districts of Dushanbe (Firdawsi, Shomansur, 
Sino, and Somoni), and the cities of Kulyab and Kurgantyube. The MOLSP will conduct an 
independent evaluation of the pilot to (i) determine the improvements in efficiency and quality of 
service provided to pensioners (including a gender analysis which assesses the impact on men 
and women), (ii) determine the number of ghost pensioners identified and the resulting cost 
savings,  and  (iii)  identify  gaps  and  develop  recommendations  for  improvement.  Requiring 
pensioners to use plastic cards is expected to make payment of pensions more efficient and 
reduce  the  average  time  between  release  of  funds  and  the  availability  of  pensions  to 
beneficiaries from to seven days from thirty under the paper-based system. It is also expected 
to help reduce the number of ghost pensioners and other system leakages (e.g., informal 
payments to bank tellers). A second pilot will redesign and improve targeting of social assistance 
and consolidation of social benefits (subsidies for gas, electricity and child school education) to 
approximately 10,000 households in the Yavan district and the town of Istaravshan. The MOLSP 
will also conduct an independent evaluation of the second pilot program, including a gender 
analysis. Improved targeting of social assistance is expected to help ensure that the benefits are 
given  to  those  that  need  it  most. This  will  help  improve  the  social safety  net systems  in

3.  Output 3: Selected Aspects of Public Financial Management Improved 
 
17.  The program will support increased transparency and efficiency in public expenditures 
through the implementation of a new Law on Internal Audit in the Public Sector, enacted in 2010. 
This law requires internal audit units to be established in government bodies that have annual 
funding from the state budget exceeding a threshold amount. The program will also support the 
enactment and implementation of a new Law on Public Finances to unify the Medium-Term 
Expenditure Framework with the annual budgeting process. 
 
D.  Program Costs and Financing 
 
18.  The government has requested a grant of $45 million from the Asian Development Fund 
(ADF).19 The grant size is based on the estimated cost of reforms, the social expenditure needs 
of the government, and the availability of ADF resources for Tajikistan. The government has 
committed to spend approximately $41 million of the $45 million grant on social safety net 
expenditures (Table 3 and the use of program proceeds).20 
 
19.  The grant will be released in two tranches: the $20 million first tranche will be released upon 
grant effectiveness; the $25 million second tranche is expected to be released in August 2012, 
subject  to  compliance  with  the  agreed-upon  conditions.  The  program  design  will  provide  an 
incentive tranche, through which $12 million of the second tranche may be disbursed early if certain 
second tranche conditions are complied with by the end of 2011. The incentive tranche is designed 
to (i) keep the reform program on track and reward efficient implementation by the government,          
(ii) allow the government to receive part of the funds by the end of 2011 for use in 2012, and         
(iii) facilitate regular review and effective monitoring of the pace and direction of reforms.

21.  Procurement and withdrawal procedures. Grant proceeds will be used to pay for 
items procured in ADB member countries, other than the items specified in the list of ineligible 
items21 and imports financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. The proceeds of the 
program  grant  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  ADB’s  simplified 
disbursement  procedures  and  related  requirements  for  program  grants.22 Grant  proceeds 
 
disbursed against imports will require a certificate from the government stipulating that the value 
of the total imports of Tajikistan, minus its imports from nonmember countries, ineligible imports, 
and imports financed under other official development assistance, is equal to or greater than the 
amount of the grant expected to be disbursed during a particular year.  
 
22.  The government will establish a subaccount in the Treasury Single Account (referred to 
as the special account) with the National Bank of Tajikistan (NBT). The grant proceeds will be 
credited into a foreign currency (dollar) account established in the NBT. Counterpart funds will 
be generated by converting the grant proceeds to somoni using the official exchange rate, and 
such counterpart funds will be credited into the special account. The crediting of the special 
account will be done within 5 days of the disbursement of each tranche of the grant. The NBT 
will provide ADB with official notification that the counterpart funds generated from the grant

IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Governance 
 
24.  Tajikistan compares poorly with other countries of the region on accountability, control of 
corruption,  government  effectiveness,  and  regulatory  quality.  The  Public  Expenditure  and 
Financial Accountability assessment completed in May 200725 highlights a number of risks, 
particularly in predictability and control in budget execution, accounting, recording and reporting, 
and external audit.26 While many of these weaknesses persist, the government continues to 
undertake  governance  and  public  financial  management  reforms  with  development  partner 
assistance.27 In recent years, important reforms have been put in place to (i) streamline the 
permits  and  inspection  regimes,  which  is  expected  to  improve  the  business  climate; 
(ii) restructure the government administration and reform pay and incentives in order to promote 
a  more  professional  civil  service;  (iii)  strengthen  public  financial  management,  including 
enactment of new laws on public procurement and internal audit, as well as reform of the tax 
administration and improvements in the budget process, all of which are expected to increase 
public accountability and transparency; and (iv) improve public service delivery. Most of these 
reforms  are  being  supported  by  development  partners,  including  ADB  (footnote  18).  The

B.  Poverty and Social 
 
26.  Over  the  short  term,  the  program  is  designed  to  help  ensure  that  critical  social 
expenditures are maintained. If such expenditures are not made, poverty incidence will be 
higher. Over the medium to long term, improving tax policy and tax administration should 
increase government revenues. The government is committed to using a substantial portion of 
incremental tax revenues received to increase social expenditures, which is expected to have a 
positive impact on poverty reduction. The program also supports improved targeting of social 
expenditures,  which  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  because  a  larger  portion  of  such 
expenditures will be received by the poorest segments of the population. 
 
27.  Tajikistan’s social situation exhibits certain gender inequalities, which are reflected in the 
delivery of social services by the social protection system. For example, (i) female pensioners 
are poorer than male pensioners and depend more on state pensions (women can accumulate 
less pension insurance as only 14% of women are in formal employment and women receive 
less than half of men’s wages on average),29 (ii) households headed by women depend more on 
social benefits (11% of household income comes from social benefits, compared to 4% in 
households headed by men),30 and (iii) women pensioners make up a majority of pensioners 
(56.3% in 2005).31 Women are often not aware of their rights under the social protection system. 
Women in Tajikistan mostly live in households headed by men and thus receive social benefits 
through  the  registered  household  head.  This  dependence  on  the  male  household  head 
becomes  a  constraint  when  male  migrant  workers  leave  behind  their  wives,  sisters,  and 
mothers, who then receive social benefits only through the registered name of their male 
relatives. Moreover, it is difficult to monitor and evaluate the gender impacts of the social 
benefits system as sex-disaggregated indicators do not exist. 
 
28.  The program will seek to address some of these challenges. First, the Tax Committee 
will approve a policy to train all women professional and support staff in the LTI. This should 
improve their chance for career progression in an agency which has very few women at senior 
levels.  Second,  at  least  20% of the  members of  the  Business  Consultative Group  will  be 
women. Third, the gender impact of the two pilot social service delivery projects supported by 
the program will be analyzed, and recommendations will be made to ensure that gender issues 
are taken into account during project expansion.
